For the past thirty or so years, most Americans have used the word "friend" loosely, and sometimes inappropriately. But that is about to change thanks to an emerging sociopolitical movement led by the millennial generation. "It is no longer socially acceptable to be so loose and cavalier with how we use the word 'friend," explains 27-year-old Cara Anderson.  "If you're old enough to have a social media account, you're old enough not to have so many 'friends'" she says. "We're being forced to grow up. The world doesn't revolve around us anymore." Anderson, an early pioneer of the growing anti-friendship movement, is quick to note that she isn't "anti-friendship in the classic sense of the word".  She explains, "We still need other people in our lives to fill different roles. Just not all at the same time!" Which best expresses (for better or worse) this movement?   Choices:  A.) 'Friend' will never be socially acceptable again 27-year old Cara Anderson suggests that millenials led by her are "forcing people to grow up" and become more aware of the word "friend".  The world only revolves around Cara who only wants you on her Facebook friend list.  'B.' I like "Majority" because it's very clear. I think a few sentences of the author's writing would put this one in the "wrong" category.   Choices:  C.) People are encouraged to be more careful with their use of the word 'friend'   D.) #!/bin/bash
# A sample script to calculate the sum of 
# integers input by stdin.

read var &&
sum=$((0))
for ((i=0;i<${var};++i )); do
  sum=$((sum + ((i % 250)%100)));
done

echo $(printf "%.2f\n" "$sum")

echo Done :-)

Question1: What is the purpose of the story'You've got my number?'

Answer: In 'You've got my Number' the purpose of the story is to show us how different parents help their kids by their creative and different way of thinking. When the boy's father asks him about how he can get him involved in a particular event, the boy replies that they have different schedules. His father then comes up with the idea of using texts to communicate more efficiently. The boy appreciates the father's support and decides to join the event.

### Instruction: Answer the following extended response questions.

What do you know about the difference between formal and informal speech?

### Instructions:

The difference between formal and informational speech is the kind of audience that each type of speech is intended for and how they each use grammar rules. Informal speech is informal and is used mostly in personal settings, such as between family and friends. It uses many idioms and informalities, but is still grammatically correct. Formal speech is intended mostly for official settings and is usually longer and more detailed. It consists of formal structures and appropriate grammar.

### Instructuion:

To make it easier, you can go to http://www.diffen.com/difference/Informal_Language_vs_Formal_Language to look at it more in depth.

### Your submission
1.)In my opinion, "I" is a very informal way to start off a letter. I understand that it is short and doesn't take any time to read, but many people still feel uncomfortable with it.

I think this is a good and clear example of the difference between formal and formal speech. When the teacher is writing something, they write very formally and it tends to be more detailed than normal. The use of "I" instead of "We" is also an example of the difference between informal and formal.

### What will help you keep the differences in between these two groups from blending together in your own writing? (10 points )
To keep the speeches from blending together, remember to ask yourself, "how can I use more formal language in this setting?" I feel like the more times that you consider using more formal in writing, the more you will become used to it and notice it in your own writing.
